description: Borrowed from Latin intercurrens, equivalent to inter- +â€Ž current.

examples: Nor did he onely stand and keep at bay this multiply'd contest; but (as if this had not been task enough) besides the intercurrent offices of life, his reception of Visits, answering of Letters, his constant Preaching and Catechising, he found leisure to write his Tract of Fundamentals, his Paraenesis, his Review of the Annotations

entries.meaning: (medicine, of a disease or condition) Simultaneous; occurring at the same time as, or during the period of, another condition.
examples: In intercurrent pneumonia, or such as occurs in the course of another disease, the absence of the characteristic expectoration, according to M. Andral, is noticed.

entries.meaning: (medicine, of a disease or condition) Not belonging to any particular season.

examples: As fatigue increases, the perception of the intercurrent excitation is retarded; an odor is perceived as exciting before it is perceived as a differentiated sensation
